mnd6:48.1: "Neither lovely nor unlovable": "Lovely," there are two types of lovely:
mnd6:48.2: sentient beings or deeds. What are lovely beings? Here, whoever is a mother, or
mnd6:48.3: father, or brother, or sister, or son, or daughter, or friend, or colleague, or
mnd6:48.4: relatives, who are of interest to him, or who want to be beneficial, or who want
mnd6:48.5: to stay away from the harness, or those with blood (kin), these are lovely
mnd6:48.6: beings. What are attractive behaviors? Desirable forms, desirable sounds,
mnd6:48.7: desirable smells, desirable flavors, desirable touches, these are lovely
mnd6:48.8: behaviors. There are two types of "unlovable": beings or deeds. What are
mnd6:48.9: unlovable beings? Here, where they are not of interest to him, do not want to
mnd6:48.10: benefit, want to stay stable, want to kill them, these are unlovable beings.
mnd6:48.11: What are the unlovable behaviors? Unpleasant forms, unpleasant sounds,
mnd6:48.12: unpleasant smells, unpleasant tastes, unpleasant touches, these are unlovable
mnd6:48.13: behaviors. "Neither lovely nor unlovable": "These are my lovely sentient beings;
mnd6:48.14: these are desirable deeds." Not to make something lovely because of greed.
mnd6:48.15: "These are my unlovable sentient beings; these are undesirable deeds." Not to
mnd6:48.16: make something unlovable because of hatred; to not make it happen, not make it
mnd6:48.17: produced, not make it arise, not make it be born.

mnd6:58.3: see, does not think think from what they see, does not think 'what I see is

mnd6:58.5: This was said by the Blessed One: "Bhikkhus! 'I am,' this is thinking; 'I am
mnd6:58.6: this,' this is thinking; 'I will be,' this is thinking; 'I will not,' this is
mnd6:58.7: thinking; 'I will be formed,' this is thinking; 'I will be formless,' this is
mnd6:58.8: thinking; 'I will be thinking,' this is thinking; 'I will be without thinking,'
mnd6:58.9: this is thinking; 'I will be thinking, not thinking,' this is thinking.
mnd6:58.10: Bhikkhus! Thinking is a disease, thinking is a tumor, thinking is an arrow,
mnd6:58.11: thinking is a curse. Bhikkhus! Therefore, here, 'we must live with an unthinking
mnd6:58.12: mind.' Bhikkhus! You should learn this way." [SN.35.248]
